This article presents lists of the literary events and publications in '''1729'''.
==Events== *[[Charles Perrault]]'s ''[[Histoires ou contes du temps passé]]'' ([[1697 in literature|1697]]) is translated into English for the first time, by Robert Samber as ''Histories or Tales of Past Times, told by Mother Goose'', including such favourite [[fairy tale]]s as ''[[Cinderella]]'', ''[[Little Red Riding Hood]]'' and ''[[Puss in Boots]]''. *The [[Derge Parkhang|Derge Sutra Printing Temple]], one of the most important cultural, social, religious and historical institutions in [[Tibet]], is founded by Dongba Tseren.
==New books== ===Prose=== *[[Eliza Haywood]] (attributed) – ''The Fair Hebrew'' *[[James Bramston]] – ''The Art of Politics'' *[[Henry Carey (writer)|Henry Carey]] – ''Poems on Several Occasions'' *Edward Cooke – ''Battel of the Poets'' *[[Thomas Cooke (author)|Thomas Cooke]] – Tales, Epistles, Odes, Fables'' *[[Daniel Defoe]] as Andrew Moreton, Esq. – ''[[Second Thoughts are Best|Second Thoughts are Best: or, a Further Improvement of a Late Scheme to Prevent Street Robberies]]'' *[[William Hatchett]] – ''The Adventures of Abdalla'' (translated from the French of [[Jean-Paul Bignon]] first published in Paris, 1712, as ''Les Avantures d'Abdalla'') *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''The Fair Hebrew; or, A True, but Secret History of Two Jewish Ladies'' *[[Thomas Innes (historian)|Thomas Innes]] – ''Critical Essay on the Ancient Inhabitants of the Northern Parts of Britain'' *[[Soame Jenyns]] – ''The Art of Dancing'' *[[William Law]] – ''A Serious Call to a Devout and Holy Life'' (extremely popular devotional manual) *[[Daniel Mace (biblical scholar)|Daniel Mace]] – ''The New Testament in Greek and English'' (a diaglot) *[[Isaac Newton]] – ''The Mathematical Principles of Natural Philosophy'' (English translation of Newton's Latin work) *[[John Oldmixon]] – ''The History of England, during the Reigns of the Royal House of Stuart'' *[[William Pulteney, 1st Earl of Bath|William Pulteney]] – ''The Honest Jury'' *[[James Ralph]] – ''Clarinda'' *[[Elizabeth Rowe]] – ''Letters on Various Occasions'' *[[Richard Savage (poet)|Richard Savage]] – ''The Wanderer'' *[[Thomas Sherlock]] – ''The Tryal of the Witnesses of the Resurrection of Jesus'' *[[Jonathan Swift]] **''An Epistle Upon an Epistle From a Certain Doctor to a Certain Great Lord'' **''[[A Modest Proposal]]'' *[[William Wycherley]] – ''The Posthumous Works of William Wycherley'' ii. (see [[1728 in literature|1728]]) *[[Benito Jerónimo Feijoo]] – ''Ilustración apologética''
===Children=== *[[Robert Samber]] as ''Histories or Tales of Past Times, told by Mother Goose''
===Drama=== *[[Colley Cibber]] – ''Love in a Riddle'' *[[Charles Coffey]] – ''The Beggar's Wedding'' *[[John Gay]] – ''Polly'' (sequel to ''The Beggar's Opera'', banned from performance by [[Robert Walpole|Walpole]]) *[[Eliza Haywood]] – ''Frederick'' *[[Charles Johnson (writer)|Charles Johnson]] – ''The Village Opera'' (opera) *[[Samuel Johnson (dramatist)]] – ''[[Hurlothrumbo]], or The Supernatural'' *Thomas Odell **''The Patron'' **''The Smugglers'' *[[Thomas Southerne]] – ''Money the Mistress'' *[[James Thomson (poet)|James Thomson]] – ''Britannia''
===Poetry=== *[[Moses Browne]] – ''Piscatory Eclogues'' *[[Alexander Pope]] – ''[[The Dunciad]], Variorum''
==Births== *[[January 12]] – [[Edmund Burke]], Irish political writer and politician (died [[1797 in literature|1797]]) *[[January 22]] – [[Gotthold Ephraim Lessing]], German writer, dramatist and critic (died [[1781 in literature|1781]]) *[[January 23]] - [[Clara Reeve]], English novelist (died [[1807 in literature|1807]])<ref>{{cite web |title=Reeve, Clara (1729–1807), novelist and poet |url=http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-23292 |website=Oxford Dictionary of National Biography |accessdate=23 August 2018 |language=en |doi=10.1093/ref:odnb/9780198614128.001.0001/odnb-9780198614128-e-23292}}</ref> *[[April 13]] – [[Thomas Percy (Bishop of Dromore)|Bishop Thomas Percy]], poet, translator and bishop (died [[1811 in literature|1811]]) *[[August 11]] – [[Ponce Denis Écouchard Lebrun]], French poet (died [[1807 in literature|1807]]) *[[September 6]] – [[Moses Mendelssohn]], German philosopher of the ''[[Haskalah]]'' or Jewish enlightenment (died [[1786 in literature|1786]]) *[[September 25]] – [[Christian Gottlob Heyne]] German classicist and archaeologist (died [[1812 in literature|1812]]) *[[September 29]] – [[John Duncombe (writer)|John Duncombe]], English poet, antiquary and cleric (died [[1786 in literature|1786]]) *''Unknown dates'' **[[Thomas Hawkins (literary editor)|Thomas Hawkins]], English editor and cleric (died [[1772 in literature|1772]])
==Deaths== *[[January 19]] – [[William Congreve]], English dramatist and poet (born [[1670 in literature|1670]])<ref>{{cite web |title=William Congreve {{!}} English dramatist |url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Congreve |website=Encyclopedia Britannica |accessdate=23 August 2018 |language=en}}</ref> *[[May 17]] – [[Samuel Clarke]], English philosopher and cleric (born [[1675 in literature|1675]]) *[[September 1]] – [[Richard Steele]], Irish journalist, satirist and dramatist (born [[1672 in literature|1672]]) *[[October 9]] – Sir [[Richard Blackmore]], English poet and religious writer (born [[1654 in literature|1654]]) *[[November 16]] – [[Abel Boyer]], French-born lexicographer, journalist and miscellanist (born c. 1667) *[[December 13]] – [[Anthony Collins]], English philosopher (born [[1676 in literature|1676]]) *''Unknown date'' – [[Gershom Carmichael]], Scottish philosopher (born c. 1672)

{{Infobox person | name = Alfred Lindon | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Alfred Lindenbaum | birth_date = {{circa|lk=no|1867}} | birth_place = [[Kraków]], [[Prussia]] | death_date = {{death year and age|1948|1867}} | death_place = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = | other_names = | known_for = | education = | employer = | occupation = Jeweller, art collector | title = | salary = | networth = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | boards = | religion = | spouse =Fernande Citroën | children ={{hlist|Lucien Lindon|Maxime Lindon|Raymond Lindon|Maurice Lindon|Jacques Lindon}} | parents =Moses Lindenbaum
Caroline Weil | relatives =[[André Citroën]] (brother-in-law)
[[Jerome Lindon]] (grandson)
[[Vincent Lindon]] (great-grandson) | box_width = }} '''Alfred Lindon''' (born '''Abner Lindenbaum'''; {{circa|lk=no|1867}} – 1948) was a Polish jeweller from a poor Jewish background who became an expert on pearls. He married into the Citroën family and built an important collection of modern art that was looted by the [[Nazi Germany|Nazis]] in occupied Paris during the [[World War II|Second World War]]. He lived to see some of his paintings returned, although others were returned to his heirs after his death. ==Early life and family== Lindon was born Abner Lindenbaum around 1867 in [[Kraków]], [[Prussia|Austria]], a region that is now in Poland. His father was Moses Lindenbaum and his mother was Caroline Weil. He married Fernande Citroën (1874–1963), sister of the motor manufacturer [[André Citroën]], and they had five sons, Lucien, Maxime, Raymond, Maurice and Jacques. His grandson [[Jérôme Lindon]] (d. 2001), Raymond's son, became an important figure in French publishing.[http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=eac07a76-c153-4284-8711-d209c68f48a0 "In 1940 Paris, there was little time to mourn the loss of art."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150428135046/http://www.canada.com/story.html?id=eac07a76-c153-4284-8711-d209c68f48a0 |date=2015-04-28 }} ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]'', 17 January 2004. canada.com Retrieved 31 January 2015. His great grandsons are the journalist and writer [[Mathieu Lindon]], and the actor [[Vincent Lindon]]. ==Career== [[File:25 Hatton Garden.jpg|thumb|25 Hatton Garden in 2005]] Lindenbaum worked in the jewellery business, becoming an expert in [[pearls]]. He was in partnership with Adolf Weil and Lewis Lindenbaum as a diamond merchant at 25 [[Hatton Garden]], London, and 48 [[rue La Fayette]], Paris, where they traded as Lindenbaum and Weil. The firm had been trading since at least the early 1890s. In 1901 it was the buyer of a six-row Napoleonic necklace of [[pearls]] for £20,000 at Christie's in London.[http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=NZH19010907.2.79.15 TWENTY THOUSAND POUND NECKLACE.] ''[[The New Zealand Herald]]'', Volume XXXVIII, Issue 11753, 7 September 1901, p. 2. ''Papers Past''. Retrieved 7 February 2015. That partnership was dissolved at the end of 1911.[https://www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/28569/page/164 Partnership dissolutions] in ''[[The London Gazette]]'', 5 January 1912, p. 5. Thereafter, Weil and the Lindenbaums bid separately for expensive pearls in London auctions. In 1916, a Lindenbaum was the under bidder on a pearl necklace at Christie's that sold for £24,000."£24,000 For a Pearl Necklace", ''[[The Times]]'', 21 June 1916, p. 5. Lindenbaum changed his name to Alfred Lindon during the First World War as he thought that name would be more acceptable than a German-sounding name.[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6422729 ''Painting Stolen During WW II Returned to France''.] [[National Public Radio]], 2 November 2006. Retrieved 5 February 2015. He also abandoned his Polish nationality and became a British citizen.[http://richardjeanjacques.blogspot.co.uk/2010/10/lhistoire-dune-perlede-citroen-vincent.html "L'Histoire d'une perle: De CITROËN à Vincent LINDON"], Jean-Jacques Richard, ''Bijoux et Pierres Precieuses'', 19 October 2010. Retrieved 8 February 2015. ==Life in Paris== Provenance records suggest that Lindon began to be a serious buyer of art around the late 1920s or early 1930s.[[Nancy Yeide|Yeide, Nancy H.]] (2009) ''Beyond the Dreams of Avarice: The Hermann Goering Collection.'' Dallas: Laurel Publishing. {{ISBN|0977434915}} In 2006, his grandson Denis Lindon (Raymond's son) remembered visiting Alfred at his home in Paris (Avenue Foch[http://www.fold3.com/image/270133221/ M1944, p. 1102.] Records of the American Commission for the Protection and Salvage of Artistic and Historical Monuments in War Areas (The Roberts Commission), 1943–1946. ''fold3''. Retrieved 8 February 2015. {{subscription required}}) when he would have been in his 60s or 70s: "He was a ''bon vivant'', we should call him. He liked his food. He was rather fat because he ate too much. He was also fond of music and he read, but art was really the centre of his life." But there was another side to Lindon. Denis recalled that his grandfather "was always very anxious—he was very Jewish in that respect. He was worried about the future, always pessimistic". Denis put it down to his background. "He'd had a difficult youth and had the Jewish spirit—he was always thinking that things were going to be difficult. But maybe that saved his life because if he wasn't pessimistic maybe he would've stayed in Paris and ended up in Auschwitz." ==Second World War== [[File:RMS Duchess of Atholl.jpg|thumb|RMS ''Duchess of Atholl'', the ship on which the Lindons made their escape to North America]] Lindon and his wife left Paris for London soon after the [[Battle of France|German invasion of France]] in 1940. They travelled from Liverpool to Montreal, Canada, on the [[RMS Duchess of Atholl|RMS ''Duchess of Atholl'']], departing on 17 August 1940.[http://search.findmypast.co.uk/record?id=tna%2fbt27%2f1556000055%2f00702 "Passenger Lists leaving UK 1890–1960 Transcription"] ''findmypast''. {{Subscription required}}The ship was sunk by a German torpedo in 1942. They eventually arrived in America where they remained for the rest of the Second World War. Before leaving Paris they placed their collection of art in the care of the [[rue Cambon]] branch of the [[Chase Manhattan Bank]], possibly because America was not then at war with Germany and they believed that their possessions would be safe in an American bank. The Chase bank was one of the few American banks that continued to trade in France after the German occupation. Presumably unknown to the Lindons, the manager of the Paris branch, [[Carlos Niedermann]], had close links with the Nazi regime.{{cite book|author=Bazyler, Michael J.|title=Holocaust Justice: The Battle for Restitution in America's Courts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3h6MVlpGYbYC&pg=PA186|year=2003|publisher=New York University Press|location=New York|isbn=978-0-8147-9904-8|page=186}} Soon after the Nazis reached Paris in June 1940, the ''Devisenschutz-Kommando'' (Commando for the Protection of Currency), raided the Chase bank looking for currency. They found instead Lindon's paintings which they seized.[http://www.fold3.com/image/292793575/ M1949, p. 25], Records of the Monuments, Fine Arts, and Archives (MFAA) Section of the Preparations and Restitution Branch, OMGUS, 1945-1951. ''fold3''. Retrieved 9 February 2015. {{subscription required}} These were later transferred to the [[Einsatzstab Reichsleiter Rosenberg]] (ERR), the chief looting organisation of the regime, whose job was to trawl occupied territory for art and antiques to transport back to Germany for Hitler's planned [[Führermuseum]] and the collections of top Nazis such as [[Hermann Göring]]. Among the paintings taken by the Nazis was [[Édouard Vuillard]]'s ''Le Salon de Madame Aron'' (1911–12) an important ''intimisme'' work that provides an insight into middle-class life in France in the early 20th century. The painting was not returned to Lindon's heirs until 2006 after the [[National Gallery of Canada]] identified it as a work with an incomplete [[provenance]] and advertised its existence. Alfred's son, Jacques, an art dealer, twice denied that the painting had belonged to his father before the French authorities released new information from German records taken at the time which proved that the painting had belonged to Alfred. As none of his approximately 15 descendants could afford to buy the others out, the painting was auctioned by Christie's in New York in 2006, selling for $912,000.[http://www.christies.com/lotfinder/lot/edouard-vuillard-le-salon-de-madame-aron-4807486-details.aspx?intObjectID=4807486 SALE 1722 Lot 35.] [[Christie's]]. Retrieved 5 February 2015.[http://www.lootedart.com/news.php?r=ML674V829241 News: National Gallery to return painting looted by Nazis (Piece is first plundered art found in Canada).] lootedart.com. Retrieved 5 February 2015. Also taken was [[Claude Monet]]'s ''La rue Montorgueil, à Paris. Fête du 30 juin 1878'', which entered the Göring Collection via the ERR in 1941. It depicts the patriotic scene in [[rue Montorgueil]] on the day of a feast that was a precursor to the current [[Bastille Day]]. It was recovered in ItalyYeide, p. 464, D78. after the war and displayed at a special exhibition at the ''[[Galerie Nationale du Jeu de Paume]]'' in 1946 of recovered art. It is now in the [[Musée d'Orsay]].[http://www.musee-orsay.fr/en/collections/index-of-works/notice.html?no_cache=1&nnumid=10896&cHash=e47419cae2 Claude Monet ''La rue Montorgueil, à Paris. Fête du 30 juin 1878''.] Musée d'Orsay. Retrieved 5 February 2015. [[Vincent van Gogh]]'s, ''Flowers in a Vase'', also from the Lindon collection, was one of 25 pictures from various sources exchanged by Göring for [[old master]] works from [[Theodor Fischer (auctioneer)|Galerie Fischer]] in 1941.Yeide, pp. 447 & 458 D36. Édouard Vuillard, Le Salon de Madame Aron, 1911-12.jpg|Édouard Vuillard, ''Le Salon de Madame Aron'', 1911–12 Monet-montorgueil.JPG|Claude Monet, ''La rue Montorgueil, à Paris. Fête du 30 juin 1878'', 1878 Van Gogh - Glas mit Feldblumen.jpeg|Vincent van Gogh, ''Flowers in a Vase'', 1890 ==Post-war== Lindon and his wife returned to Paris after the end of the Second World War in time to see some of their paintings recovered. According to Denis Lindon, who lived with his parents and siblings at his grandfather's home after the war, the contents were intact as the [[Gestapo]] had set up office in the building. His grandfather's tapestries and 18th-century furniture were still there, and only the paintings were missing. Alfred Lindon died in 1948. ==Notes and references== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category inline|Alfred Lindon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lindon, Alfred}} [[Category:1860s births]] [[Category:1948 deaths]] [[Category:French people of Polish-Jewish descent]] [[Category:Jewish art collectors]] [[Category:Subjects of Nazi art appropriations]] [[Category:People from Kraków]]

{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Amina Shah | image = Amina_Shah_(writer_and_storyteller).jpg | imagesize = 220px | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth-date|31 October 1918}} | birth_place = [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]] | death_date = {{death-date and age|19 January 2014|31 October 1918}}<ref name="Death Certificate">{{cite web | last = Staff | first = | title = Death Certificate of Amina Maxwell-Hudson (nee Shah) | publisher = [[The Idries Shah Foundation]] | work = [[General Register Office for England and Wales]] | date = 19 January 2014 | url = https://idriesshahfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Amina-Shah-death-certificate.pdf | accessdate = 5 March 2018 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180305182725/https://idriesshahfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/Amina-Shah-death-certificate.pdf | archive-date = 5 March 2018 | dead-url = no}}</ref> | death_place = [[Golders Green]], [[London]], [[England]] | occupation = Author, poet, storyteller | nationality = Afghan, British | period = | genre = | subject = Storytelling, travel, exploration, Arab World, cross-cultural studies | movement = | spouse = | partner = | relatives = [[:category:Shah family|Shah family]] | influences = }}
'''Amina Shah''' (31 October 1918 – 19 January 2014), later known as '''Amina Maxwell-Hudson''',<ref name="Death Certificate" /> was a British anthologiser of [[sufism|Sufi]] stories and [[Fairy tale|folk tale]]s,<ref name=Smoley>{{cite book | last = Smoley | first = Richard |author2=Kinney, Jay | authorlink = | title = Hidden Wisdom | publisher = Quest Books | year = 2004 | location = Wheaton, IL/Chennai, India | pages = 244 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-8356-0844-1}}</ref> and was for many years the Chairperson of the [[College of Storytellers]]. She was the sister of the Sufi writers [[Idries Shah]] and [[Omar Ali-Shah]], and the daughter of [[Sirdar Ikbal Ali Shah]]<ref name=Smoley /> and [[Saira Elizabeth Luiza Shah]]. Her nephew is the travel writer and documentary filmmaker [[Tahir Shah]]; her nieces, [[Safia Shah]] and the writer and documentary filmmaker [[Saira Shah]].
==Family origins and life== Shah was born into a distinguished family of Saadat (= [[Arabic]] plural of [[Sayyid]]) who had their ancestral home at [[Paghman]], not far from [[Kabul]].<ref name=Kent>{{cite web | last = Moorhouse | first = Geoffrey | title = From Kent to Kabul | work=[[The New York Times]] | date = 26 October 2003 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/26/books/from-kent-to-kabul.html | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180305195910/http://www.nytimes.com/2003/10/26/books/from-kent-to-kabul.html | archive-date = 5 March 2018 | dead-url = no | accessdate = 23 September 2008}}</ref><ref name=IAN><!-- Please add page number -->{{Cite book | last = Shah | first = Tahir | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = In Arabian Nights | place = | publisher = | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 978-0-553-80523-9}} </ref> Her paternal grandfather, Sayyid Amjad Ali Shah, was the [[nawab]] of [[Sardhana]], in the North-Indian state of [[Uttar Pradesh]].<ref>Bashir M. Dervish: "Idris Shah: a contemporary promoter of Islamic Ideas in the West" in: Islamic Culture – an English Quarterly Vol. L, no. 4 October 1976. Published by the Islamic Culture Board, Hyderabad India (Osmania University, Hyderabad)</ref> The principality was awarded to his ancestor [[Jan-Fishan Khan]] during the [[British Raj]], and had been ruled formerly by the Kashmiri-born warrior-princess, the [[Begum Samru]].<ref name=Saira>{{Cite book | last = Shah | first = Saira | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = The Storyteller's Daughter | place = New York, NY | publisher = Anchor Books | year = 2003 | volume = | edition = | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 1-4000-3147-8}}</ref>
Her career as a folklorist and author spanned seventy years.<ref>First book 1938, most recent due out with I. B. Tauris in 2009</ref> In that time she travelled widely, collecting stories and studying folklore. Her travels took her through [[Africa]] and the [[Middle East]], through the jungles of [[Sarawak]], across the Australian [[Outback]], [[Afghanistan]], and beyond.
[[Doris Lessing]], who became a student of Idries Shah's Sufism in the 1960s, championed the Shah family's efforts to disseminate such [[teaching stories]] in the West, and penned an introduction for Amina Shah's ''The Tale of the Four Dervishes''.<ref name="Galin">{{cite book | last = Galin | first = Müge | authorlink = | title = Between East and West: Sufism in the Novels of Doris Lessing | publisher = State University of New York Press | year = 1997 | location = Albany, NY | pages = 20–21, 100 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn = 0-7914-3383-8}}</ref>
Amina Shah married and became Amina Maxwell-Hudson. She died at Golders Green, London on 19 January 2014 at the age of 95.<ref name="Death Certificate" />
==Books==
*''Tiger of the Frontier'' (1938) (as A.A.Shah) *''Folk Tales of Central Asia'' (1970) *''The Tale of the Four Dervishes'' (1979) *''The Assemblies of Al-Hariri'' (1980) *''Tales of Afghanistan'' (1982) *''Arabian Fairy Tales'' (1989) *''Tales From the Bazaars'' (2002), re-published as ''Tales from the Bazaars of Arabia: Folk Stories from the Middle East'' (2009)
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081007034229/http://www.octagonpress.com/authors/aminashah.htm Amina Shah's profile at Octagon Press]

{{Infobox magazine | title = Art Collector | image_file = | image_size = | image_caption = The current issue of Art Collector magazine, April - June 2013 | editor = Susan Borham | editor_title = Editor-in-Chief | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | frequency = Quarterly | circulation = | category = [[Visual Arts of Australia]], [[Aboriginal art|Indigenous art]] | company = | publisher = Magnesium Media | firstdate = Jul-Sep 1997 | country = [[Australia]] | based = [[Sydney]] | language = English | website = {{url|http://www.artcollector.net.au}} | issn = 1328-9586 }} '''''Art Collector''''' (formerly ''Australian Art Collector'') is a quarterly art magazine. It primarily covers Australian contemporary and Indigenous art and also features New Zealand and international artists.
==Publication== The magazine is best known for its annual feature ''50 of Australia's Most Collectable Artists'', which is referenced by other sources and collectors.<ref name="Cockington">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/investment/light-on-life/2006/10/23/1161455662681.html?page=2|title=Light on life|last=Cockington|first=James|date=25 October 2006|work=Sydney Morning Herald|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref><ref name="Crawford">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/12/13/1071125711091.html?from=storyrhs|title=Melbourne artists: the work to collect|last=Crawford|first=Ashley|date=14 December 2003|work=The Age|accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref> For a decade the list was compiled by a panel of industry experts, but since 2009 the list has been voted on by magazine subscribers.<ref>[http://www.artcollector.net.au/Issue47 Issue 47, Jan-Mar 2009, Art Collector magazine]</ref>
Art collectors featured in the magazine have included Simon Mordant, Corbett & Yueji Lyon (Lyon Housemuseum), John Kaldor and Colin & Elizabeth Laverty.
==History== ''Art Collector'' was launched in 1997 in Sydney, Australia. Shortly after its foundation the magazine was briefly in the news when text from one of its articles was used without acknowledgement by art critic [[Robert Hughes (critic)|Robert Hughes]], when writing for ''Time'' magazine.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/35722236.html?dids=35722236:35722236&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Nov+06%2C+1998&author=Mark+Jurkowitz%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe&desc=Critic+Hughes+admits+taking+writer's+words&pqatl=google|title=Critic Hughes admits taking writer's words|author=Mark Jurkowitz|date=6 November 1998|work=Boston Globe| accessdate=21 September 2010}}</ref>
In 2009, ''Art Collector'' published its first ''Guide to Indigenous Art Centres''. In the same year it also published the ''Guide to Public & Regional Galleries'' and the ''Collector's Guidebook'', a directory of services for art collectors.
In 2012, ''Art Collector'' published the third edition of the ''Guide to Indigenous Art Centres'', which featured stories on ethically sourcing Indigenous art and how to be certain of provenance. The fourth edition of the guide would be released in late 2013.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.artcollector.net.au www.artcollector.net.au] * [http://www.magnesiummedia.com.au www.magnesiummedia.com.au]

[[File:Altar to the Hand of Ezomo Ehenua (Ikegobo) MET DP234641.jpg|thumb|Ikegobo (Altar to the Hand) of Ezomo Ehenua, 18th - 19th century]]
'''Ikegobo''', the [[Edo language|Edo]] term for "altars to the Hand," are a type of cylindrical sculpture from the [[Benin Empire]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Oba with Animals, Altar to the Hand (Ikegobo) of Ezomo Ehenua [Nigeria; Edo peoples, court of Benin] (1991.17.113,1996.11)|url=http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/1991.17.113,1996.11|work=Heilbrunn Timeline of Art History|publisher=The Metropolitan Museum of Art|accessdate=3 April 2013}}</ref> Used as a cultural marker of an individual's accomplishments, Ikegobo are dedicated to the hand, from which the people of Benin considered the will for wealth and success to originate. These commemorative objects are made of wood or brass with figures carved in relief around their sides.
Ikegobo, like the royal [[Benin ancestral altars|ancestral altars]], are settings for spectacular examples of [[Benin art]].
==The cult of the Hand in Nigeria== The cult of the Hand is based on the belief that a man's right hand or arm embodies his capacity for accomplishment.<ref name=Vogel /> The cult focuses on a man's skill with tools, his economic effectiveness, and his ability to win physical contests. The Hand will also protect him and his household from attacks by malevolent spirits or human enemies.<ref name=Vogel>{{cite book|last=Vogel|first=Susan|title=Gods of Fortune: The Cult of the Hand in Nigeria|year=1974|publisher=Museum of Primitive Art|location=New York, NY}}</ref>
In Benin culture, the hand is worshiped primarily by those who have already achieved outstanding success or wealth.<ref name=Ezra />
The Benin kings and chiefs have worshiped the hand since the time of [[Oba Ewuare]], the fifteenth-century warrior king.<ref name="Egharevba 1949">{{cite book|last=Egharevba|first=Jacob|title=Benin Law and Custom|year=1949|location=Port Harcourt, Nigeria}}</ref> The wars of expansion that Ewuare waged and won not only gave him the impetus to become a devotee of the hand, but may have also exposed him to other areas of southern [[Nigeria]] where hand worship was practiced.<ref name=Dean>{{cite book|last=Dean|first=Carolyn|title=The Art of Power, The Power of Art: Studies in Benin Iconography|year=1983|publisher=University of California Press|location=Los Angeles|page=33-40|authorlink=The Individual and the Ancestral: Ikegobo and Ukurhe|editor=Paula Ben-Amos and Arnold Rubin}}</ref>
==Design and materials== Wooden altars to the hand are owned by Benin chiefs. The [[Oba (ruler)|Oba]], queen mother, and certain other privileged chiefs have the right to own cast brass ''ikegobo''.<ref name=Ezra>{{cite book|last=Ezra|first=Kate|title=Royal art of Benin : the Perls collection in the Metropolitan Museum of Art|year=1992|publisher=Metropolitan Museum of Art|location=New York|isbn=0870996320}}</ref>
The cylindrical form refers to a type of round, legless stool commonly used by the Edo in the past.<ref name=Dean /> The altar is places on an altar stand, a semicircular platform whose straight edge is extended at both sides, which is carved on its top and sides with figures and other motifs in relief. A wooden spoke at the top of the altar supports an ivory tusk.
Altars were places in the second public room of the house of traditional chiefs, on top of a polished and whitened mud platform.

{{for|the book by Thomas Frognall Dibdin|Bibliomania (book)}} [[File:Libros 2013 001.jpg|thumb|Cluttered bookshelf, one symptom of bibliomania]] '''Bibliomania''' can be a symptom of [[obsessive–compulsive disorder]] which involves the [[Book collecting|collecting]] or even [[Compulsive hoarding|hoarding]] of [[book]]s to the point where social relations or health are damaged.
Bibliomania is not to be confused with [[bibliophilia]], which is the usual love of books and is not considered a clinical psychological disorder.
==Description== One of several unusual behaviors associated with books, bibliomania is characterized by the collecting of books which have no use to the collector nor any great intrinsic value to a genuine book collector. The purchase of multiple copies of the same book and edition and the accumulation of books beyond possible capacity of use or enjoyment are frequent symptoms of bibliomania.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/in-excess/201309/hooked-and-booked|title=Hooked and Booked|website=Psychology Today|language=en|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref> Bibliomania is not a psychological disorder recognized by the [[American Psychiatric Association]] in its DSM-IV.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.inlifehealthcare.com/2015/09/09/a-detailed-study-about-bibliomania/|title=A Detailed Study About Bibliomania|last=Agrawal|first=Mukta|date=2015-09-09|website=InlifeHealthCare|access-date=2017-05-25}}</ref>
The term was coined by [[John Ferriar]] (1761–1815), a physician at the Manchester Royal Infirmary.<ref>Kendall, Joshua. ''The man who made lists: love, death, madness, and the creation of [[Roget's Thesaurus]]'', Penguin Group, USA, 2008, p. 154.</ref> Ferriar coined the term in 1809 in a poem he dedicated to his bibliomanic friend, [[Richard Heber]] (1773–1833).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ferriar|first=John|title=The Bibliomania, An Epistle to Richard Heber, Esq.|year=1809|publisher=T. Cadell and W. Davies, in the Strand; J. Haddock, Warrington|location=London|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=1TcQz5ckEjUC&oi=fnd&pg=PA1&dq=The+Bibliomania:+An+Epistle+to+Richard+Heber&ots=_v8s1F-1sn&sig=NWFjbept8w3GKdrW--nJW6mPon0#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> In the early nineteenth century, "bibliomania" was used in popular discourse (such as in periodical essays and poems) to describe obsessive book collectors.
In 1809, the Reverend [[Thomas Frognall Dibdin]] published ''Bibliomania; or Book Madness'', a work described by literary critic Philip Connell as "a series of bizarre rambling dialogues which together comprised a kind of dramatized mock pathology, lavishly illustrated and, in the second edition, embellished with extensive footnotes on bibliography and the history of book collecting." The "symptoms" displayed by the biblomaniacs in Dibdin's work include "an obsession with uncut copies, fine paper or [[vellum]] pages, unique copies, [[first edition]]s, [[blackletter]] books, illustrated copies, association copies, and condemned or suppressed works".<ref>{{cite journal|last=Connell|first=Philip|title=Bibliomania: Book Collecting, Cultural Politics, and the Rise of Literary Heritage in Romantic Britain|journal=Representations|date=Summer 2000|volume=71|pages=24–47|doi=10.1525/rep.2000.71.1.01p00764}}</ref>
In the late nineteenth century, book collections and collectors of note were given regular coverage as curiosities.<ref> {{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article138654887 |title=LITERATURE. |newspaper=[[The Australasian]] |volume=LIV, |issue=1415 |location=Victoria, Australia |date=13 May 1893 |accessdate=18 November 2017 |page=45 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
[[Holbrook Jackson]] was to follow the work of Ferriar and Dibdin later in the work ''The Anatomy of Bibliomania''<ref>{{Citation | author1=Jackson, Halbrook | title=The Anatomy of bibliomania | publication-date=1930 | publisher=The Soncino Press | edition=1st | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8604238 | accessdate=18 November 2017 }}, also {{Citation | author1=Jackson, Holbrook | title=The anatomy of bibliomania | publication-date=1932 | publisher=Soncino Press | edition=3rd ed., rev | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/8604238 | accessdate=18 November 2017 }}</ref>
==People with bibliomania== * [[Stephen Blumberg]], who was convicted of stealing $5.3 million worth of books. * [[Thomas Phillipps|Sir Thomas Phillipps, 1st Baronet]]<ref>[http://www.maggs.com/collections/onlycollect.asp?book=17&page=3 Book Collecting: A.N.L. Munby: A Balanced View<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> (1792–1872) suffered from severe bibliomania. His collection, which at his death contained over 160,000 books and manuscripts, was still being auctioned off over 100 years after his death. * Rev. W.F. Whitcher<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1881/07/28/archives/a-book-thief-a-providence-preachers-strange-transactions-in-rare.html | work=The New York Times | title=A Book Thief.; A Providence Preacher's Strange Transactions In Rare Volumes | date=1881-07-28 | accessdate=2010-04-26}}</ref> was a 19th-century [[Methodism|Methodist]] pastor who, after having stolen and rebound rare books, would assert they were rare "finds" from local booksellers.
==Depictions in fiction== *Peter Kien, the protagonist in [[Auto-da-Fé (novel)|''Auto-da-Fé'']] by [[Elias Canetti]]. Kien's obsession with his personal library leads to the destruction of his marriage, his happiness, and ultimately the library itself. *[[Yomiko Readman]], the protagonist in ''[[Read or Die]]'', is an introverted bibliomaniac, often preferring the company of books over people. * [[Don Vincente]], a fictional Spanish monk who was suspected of stealing books from his monastery, and later murdered nine people so he could steal their books.
==See also== *[[Tsundoku]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Dibdin | first = Thomas Frognall | title = [[Bibliomania (book)|Bibliomania]]: Or Book Madness | year = 1811 }} ( Dibdin's {{gutenberg|no=28540|name=Bibliomania}}) {{external media | width = 210px | align = right | headerimage= | video1 = [https://www.c-span.org/video/?67215-1/gentle-madness ''Booknotes'' interview with Nicholas Basbanes on ''A Gentle Madness'', October 15, 1995], [[C-SPAN]]}} *{{cite book | last = Basbanes | first = Nicholas A. | authorlink = Nicholas A. Basbanes | title = A Gentle Madness: Bibliophiles, Bibliomanes, and the Eternal Passion for Books | publisher = Henry Holt and Company, Inc. | year = 1995 }} *{{cite book|last=Bartlett|first=Allison Hoover|title=The Man Who Loved Books Too Much: The True Story of a Thief, a Detective, and a World of Literary Obsession|year=2009|publisher=Riverhead Trade|location=New York}} *[[Richard de Bury]] (1902). The love of books: ''[[The Philobiblon]]'' translated by E. C. Thomas. London: Alexander Moring *[[Andrew Lang]] (1881). ''[[The Library (book)|The Library]]''.London, Macmillan & Co. **{{cite book | last = McDade | first = Travis | title = The Book Thief | publisher = Praeger | location = Westport, CT | year = 2006 | isbn = 0-275-99331-0 }}

'''Carl-Herman Tillhagen''' (17 December 1906 - 28 May 2002) was a Swedish [[folklorist]]<ref>http://goliath.ecnext.com/coms2/gi_0199-5422561/Spatial-representation-in-European-popular.html</ref> and [[ethnologist]] who did extensive research on [[Scandinavian folklore]].
== Life == He was born on 17 December 1906 in [[Sundsvall]], Sweden. From 1932 to 1936 Tillhagen studied at [[Uppsala University]]. He continued his studies at [[Stockholm University]] until 1943, and until 1960 in [[Oslo]] where he received his doctorate. In 1939 he was employed by [[Nordiska museet]], where he was a curator from 1961 to 1972.
In 1954 he was employed for a study of the [[Romani people]]. He was even on the board of directors in the [[International Society for Folk Narrative Research]]. In 1966 he was [[guest professor]] at [[Indiana University]] and [[University of California]].
== Bibliography == * ''Taikon berättar'' (1946) * ''Svenska folklekar och danser I-II'' (1949–50, med N. Denker) * ''Folklig läkekonst'' (1960) * ''Folklig spådomskonst'' (1961) * ''Papers on [[folkmedicin|Folk-Medicine]]'' (1964) * ''Zigenarna i Sverige'' (1965) * ''Glada juledagar'' (1965) * ''Fåglarna i folktron'' (1978) * ''Folklig ordakonst'' (1980) * ''Järnet och människorna, verklighet och vidskepelse'' (1981) * ''Vardagsskrock'' (1982) * ''Barnet i folktron'' (1983) * ''Jaktskrock'' (1985) * ''Arbetsliv och julglädje'' (1985) * ''Drömrosor och kärleksört'' (1985) * ''Bellmanhistorier'' (1986) * ''Vävskrock'' (1986) * ''Allmogejakt i Sverige'' (1987) * ''Malmsägner och gruvskrock'' (1988) * ''Vår kropp i folktron'' (1989) * ''Himlens stjärnor och vädrets makter'' (1991) * ''Skogarna och träden'' (1995) * ''Vattnens folklore'' (1997) * ''Bergen de blå och stenarna där barn du lekte'' (1998) * ''Våra folkminnen'' (1999)

MET DP805125.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Portrait of the Artist, 1850-1853 | native_name = | native_name_lang = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different than name --> | birth_date = c. 1826/1827 | birth_place = France | death_date = April 6, 1883 | death_place = France | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|type:landmark|display=inline}} --> | nationality = | residence = | education = [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]] | alma_mater = | known_for = ''Cours de dessin'', a classical drawing course | notable_works = | style = | movement = Orientalist scenes, historical genre | spouse = | partner = | awards = <!-- {{awd|award|year|title|role|name}} (optional) --> | elected = | patrons = | memorials = | website = <!-- {{URL|Example.com}} --> | module = }} '''Charles Bargue''' (c. 1826/1827 – April 6, 1883) was a [[France|French]] painter and lithographer noted for devising an influential drawing course.
==Life and career== [[Image:Bargue The Chess Game.jpg|thumb|''The Chess Game'', by Charles Bargue]] He is mostly remembered for his ''Cours de dessin'', one of the most influential classical drawing courses conceived in collaboration with [[Jean-Léon Gérôme]]. The course, published between 1866 and 1871 by [[Goupil & Cie]], comprised 197 [[lithograph]]s printed as individual sheets, was to guide students from plaster casts to the study of great master drawings and finally to drawing from the living model. The Charles Bargue Drawing Course is used by many academies and ateliers which focus of [[classical realism]]. Among the artists whose work is based on the study of Bargue's plate work are Pablo Picasso<ref>{{cite web|last1=Glueck|first1=Grace|title=In the Days When Artists Were Taught How to Draw|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/12/26/books/art-review-in-the-days-when-artists-were-taught-how-to-draw.html|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=27 May 2015}}</ref> and [[Vincent van Gogh]], who copied the complete set in 1880/1881, and (at least a part of it) again in 1890.
Bargue was a student of Jean-Léon Gérôme. Bargue worked closely with Gérôme and was influenced by his style, which included Orientalist scenes and historical genre. Bargue's last painting was completed by Gérôme and is now conserved in the Malden Public Library, [[Malden, Massachusetts]], USA. He travelled extensively through North Africa, and the Balkans, during which time he executed many portraits of local people with meticulous detail.

{{Redirect|Deejay|a person who verbalizes with music in the Jamaican style|Deejay (Jamaican)}} {{redirect-multi|2|DJ|DJs}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} [[File:ALEX NILSON.jpg|thumb|upright|A DJ performing at an event using [[phonograph|record turntables]] and a [[DJ mixer]], a small [[audio console|mixer]] used to transition between songs.]]
A '''disc jockey''', often abbreviated as '''DJ''', is a person who plays existing recorded [[music]] for a live audience. Most common types of DJs include [[Radio personality|radio DJ]], club DJ who performs at a [[nightclub]] or [[music festival]] and [[turntablism|turntablist]] who uses record players, usually [[turntable]]s, to manipulate sounds on [[phonograph record]]s. Originally, the disc in disc jockey referred to [[gramophone record]]s, but now DJ is used as an all-encompassing term to describe someone who mixes recorded music from any source, including [[compact cassette|cassettes]], [[Compact disc|CDs]] or [[digital audio file]]s on a [[CDJ]] or [[laptop]]. The title DJ is commonly used by DJs in front of their real names or adopted [[pseudonym]]s or [[stage name]]s.
DJs use audio equipment that can play at least two sources of recorded music simultaneously and [[audio mixing|mix them together]] to create seamless transitions between recordings and develop unique mixes of songs. Often, this involves [[beatmatching|aligning the beats]] of the music sources so their rhythms do not clash when played together or to enable a smooth transition from one song to another. DJs often use specialized [[DJ mixer]]s, small [[Audio console|audio mixers]] with [[crossfader]] and [[Cue (audio)|cue]] functions to blend or transition from one song to another. Mixers are also used to pre-listen to sources of recorded music in [[headphones]] and adjust upcoming tracks to mix with currently playing music. DJ software can be used with a [[DJ controller]] device to mix audio files on a computer instead of a console mixer. DJs may also use a [[microphone]] to speak to the audience; [[effects unit]]s such as [[reverb]] to create sound effects and [[electronic musical instrument]]s such as [[drum machine]]s and [[synthesizer]]s.
==Description== Originally, the "disc" in "disc jockey" referred to [[gramophone record]]s, but now "DJ" is used as an all-encompassing term to describe someone who mixes recorded music from any source, including [[vinyl records]], [[compact cassette|cassettes]], [[CD]]s, or [[digital audio file]]s stored on [[USB flash drive|USB stick]] or [[laptop]]. DJs typically perform for a live audience in a [[nightclub]] or dance club or a TV, radio broadcast audience, or in the 2010s, an [[online radio]] audience. DJs also create mixes, remixes and tracks that are recorded for later sale and distribution. In [[hip hop music]], DJs may create beats, using percussion [[Break (music)|break]]s, [[bassline]]s and other musical content [[sampling (music)|sampled]] from pre-existing records. In hip hop, rappers and MCs use these beats to [[rapping|rap]] over.
DJs use equipment that can play at least two sources of recorded music simultaneously and [[audio mixing|mix them together]]. This allows the DJ to create seamless transitions between recordings and develop unique mixes of songs. Often, this involves [[beatmatching|aligning the beats]] of the music sources so their rhythms do not clash when they are played together, either so two records can be played at the same time, or to enable the DJ to make a smooth transition from one song to another. An important tool for DJs is the specialized [[DJ mixer]], a small [[audio console|audio mixer]] with a [[crossfader]] and [[Cue (audio)|cue]] functions. The crossfader enables the DJ to blend or transition from one song to another. The cue knobs or switches allow the DJ to listen to a source of recorded music in [[headphones]] before playing it for the live club or broadcast audience. Previewing the music in headphones helps the DJ pick the next track they want to play, [[cue (audio)|cue up]] the track to the desired starting location, and align the two tracks' beats in traditional situations where auto sync technology is not being used. This process ensures that the selected song will mix well with the currently playing music. DJs may also use a [[microphone]] to speak to the audience; [[effects unit]]s such as [[reverb]] to create sound effects; and [[electronic musical instrument]]s such as [[drum machine]]s and [[synthesizer]]s.
The title "DJ" is also commonly used by DJs in front of their real names or adopted [[pseudonym]]s or [[stage name]]s as a title to denote their profession (e.g., [[DJ Jazzy Jeff]], [[DJ Q-bert]], [[DJ Shadow]] and [[DJ Yoda]]). Some DJs focus on creating a good mix of songs for the club dancers or radio audience. Other DJs use [[turntablism]] techniques such as "[[scratching]]", in which the DJ or [[turntablist]] manipulates the [[phonograph|record player turntable]] to create new rhythms and sounds. DJs need to have a mixture of artistic and technical skills for their profession, because they have to understand both the creative aspects of making new musical beats and tracks, and the technical aspects of using [[audio console]]s, professional audio equipment, and, in the 2010s, [[Digital Audio Workstation]]s and other computerized music gear. In many types of DJing, including club DJing and radio/TV DJing, a DJ also has to have [[charisma]] and develop a good rapport with the audience. Professional DJs often specialize in a specific genre of music, such as [[house music]] or [[hip hop music]]. DJs typically have an extensive knowledge about the music they specialize in. Many DJs are avid music collectors of vintage, rare or obscure tracks and records.
==Types==
===Radio DJs=== {{Main|Radio personality}}
Radio DJs or [[radio personality|radio personalities]] introduce and play music that is broadcast on [[AM broadcasting|AM]], [[FM broadcasting|FM]], [[Digital radio|digital]] or [[Internet radio]] stations.
===Club DJs===
[[File:Pete Rock @ The Brookyln Bowl in 2016.jpg|thumbnail|right|DJ [[Pete Rock]] performing at Razel and Friends - Brooklyn Bowl, 2016]] [[File:20021101 TRANSPLANT 10 - TALPA live - unedited.webm|thumb|right|A DJ at a techno party in 2002 in Serbia]] Club DJs, commonly referred as DJs in general, play music at musical events, such as parties at [[Nightclub|music venues]] or [[bar]]s, [[music festival]]s, corporate and private events. Typically, club DJs mix music recordings from two or more sources using different mixing techniques in order to produce non-stopping flow of music. One key technique used for seamlessly transitioning from one song to another is [[beatmatching]]. A DJ who mostly plays and mixes one specific music genre is often given the title of that genre; for example, a DJ who plays hip hop music is called a hip hop DJ, a DJ who plays house music is a house DJ, a DJ who plays techno is called a techno DJ, and so on. The quality of a DJ performance (often called a DJ mix or DJ set) consists of two main features: technical skills, or how well can DJ operate the equipment and produce smooth transitions between two or more recordings and a playlist, or ability of a DJ to select most suitable recordings also known as "reading the crowd".<ref>[https://www.digitaldjtips.com/2011/12/how-to-read-a-crowd-and-what-happens-if-you-dont/ How To Read A Crowd (And What Happens If You Don’t)], ''Digital DJ Tips'', 3 November 2017</ref>
===Turntablists=== {{Main|Turntablism}}
Turntablists, also called battle DJs, use [[Phonograph|turntables]] and [[DJ mixer]] to manipulate recorded sounds in order to produce new music. In essence, they use DJ equipment as a musical instrument. The most known turntablist technique is [[scratching]]. Turntablists often participate in DJ contests like [[DMC World DJ Championships]] and Red Bull 3Style.<ref>[http://www.redbullthre3style.com/ Red Bull 3Style]</ref>
=== Residents ===
A resident DJ performs at a venue on a regular basis or permanently.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://thump.vice.com/en_uk/article/resident-djs-are-the-unsung-heroes-of-clubbing-show-them-love|title=Resident DJs Are The Heroes Of Clubbing, And We Need To Show Them Love {{!}} Thump|last=Thorp|first=John|date=7 January 2014|newspaper=Thump|access-date=2017-02-09|publisher=Vice|work=|language=en-UK|via=}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitaldjinfo.com/what-is-resident-dj/|title=What Is "Being A Resident DJ" ? {{!}}|last=Celikbas|first=Murat|date=2013-10-01|newspaper=Digital DJ INFO|access-date=2017-02-09|work=|language=en-US|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/music/2013/11/dos-donts-resident-dj/|title=The Do's and Don'ts of Being a Weekly Resident DJ|last=|first=|date=14 November 2013|website=Complex|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> They would perform regularly (typically under an agreement) in a particular discotheque, a particular club, a particular event, or a particular broadcasting station.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://djmag.com/content/darius-syrossian-best-resident-dj|title=DARIUS SYROSSIAN (BEST RESIDENT DJ)|website=DJMag.com|language=en|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vibe.com/2013/04/resident-dj-mednas-dishes-miami-liv-ing/|title=Resident DJ Mednas Dishes On Miami LIV-ing|date=2013-04-19|newspaper=Vibe|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mmegi.bw/index.php?aid=66384&dir=2017/february/06|title=The Monitor :: Variety Of Talent At Next Big EDM DJ|last=Ncube|first=Dumisani|newspaper=The Monitor|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> Residents have a decisive influence on the club or a series of events.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.skiddle.com/news/all/mUmU-Liverpool-9th-birthday-review/30778/|title=mUmU Liverpool 9th birthday review|last=Frankland|first=Becca|date=7 February 2017|newspaper=Skiddle.com|access-date=2017-02-09|work=|language=en-gb|via=}}</ref> Per agreement with the management or company, the DJ would have to perform under agreed times and dates.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.magneticmag.com/2016/03/how-to-become-resident-dj-at-local-nightclub/|title=How to Become the Resident Dj At Your Local Nightclub|last=Robinson|first=Tyler|date=9 March 2016|website=www.magneticmag.com|language=en-us|access-date=2017-02-09}}</ref> Typically, DJs perform as residents for two or three times in a week, for example, on Friday and Saturday.
