{{Sculpture | image = | title = The Abandoned Soldier (TAS) | artist = [[James Napier (sculptor)|James Napier]] | year = 2007 | type = [[Resin]] | city = [[Unknown (placeholder)|Unknown]] | museum = [[Cardiff Castle (placeholder)|Unknown]] }}
'''''The Abandoned Soldier''''' is a sculpture created in 2007 by sculptor James Napier that was modelled after British ex-soldier Lance Corporal Daniel Twiddy.<ref>[https://thepsychologist.bps.org.uk/volume-25/edition-1/big-picture-abandoned-soldier]</ref>
==History== The sculpture ''The Abandoned Soldier'' (TAS) was made for the [[BBC]] documentary ''Power to the People'' <ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/power_to_the_people/6613759.stm Power To The People: The Battle of Trafalgar Square] BBC News</ref> to be erected in Trafalgar Square, and made an appearance on Newsnight as well as the front page of the Independent newspaper. TAS was initially housed at [[Combat Stress]], a charitable organisation for ex-servicemen and women, before being moved with the help of the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers to the [[National Memorial Arboretum]] in Staffordshire to launch The Abandoned Soldier Project. The sculpture has subsequently been moved to Cardiff Castle, then to Exeter Castle for the War Art Exhibition in June 2011, and was filmed as part of a Channel 5 documentary.<ref>[http://www.welshicons.org.uk/news/cardiff/cardiff-castle-welcomes-the-abandoned-soldier/ Cardiff Castle Welcomes The Abandoned Soldier] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20121224155540/http://www.welshicons.org.uk/news/cardiff/cardiff-castle-welcomes-the-abandoned-soldier/ |date=2012-12-24 }} WelshIcons.org.uk</ref><ref>[http://cardiffian.jomec.co.uk/article/forgotten-soldier-statue-erected-cardiff-castle Forgotten soldier statue erected by Cardiff Castle] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120131225935/http://cardiffian.jomec.co.uk/article/forgotten-soldier-statue-erected-cardiff-castle |date=2012-01-31 }} The Cardiffian</ref> From there it was moved to the Rhondda Heritage Park at [[Trehafod]].
In April 2012, the sculpture was moved back to Cardiff Castle as a permanent 'base'. In the Summer of 2013, the head piece was removed from the base and taken on a tour of Wales.<ref>[https://www.flickr.com/photos/100933196@N03/sets/72157649153200768/]</ref> The high points included; The summit of Mount Snowdon and Portmeirion.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=69WD1zeCcXU]</ref> In May 2014 the sculpture was part of an installation by Themis Jones, installed at the Hay Festival of Literature and Art. In July 2014 he returned to his main 'base' at Cardiff Castle and will stand as a lasting reminder of the trauma of War, until 2018.
==Interpretation== The statue was created in remembrance of soldiers who have suffered the after effects of armed conflict and are not being treated like the heroes they truly are.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-15533875 Garden of remembrance at heritage park to fallen troops] BBC News</ref> The sculpture was modelled after Lance Corporal Daniel Twiddy, who had been wounded in 2003 by friendly fire and shrapnel while in [[Basra]].<ref>[http://www.cavgds.co.uk/assets/89/March_09_Newsletter.pdf The Abandoned Soldier] The Cavalry and Guards Club, 127 Newsletter, March 2009</ref><ref>[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2011/02/12/sculpture-tribute-to-soldiers-hardship-91466-28158852/ Sculpture tribute to soldiers’ hardship] Wales Online</ref> Twiddy had received several wounds from shrapnel, which included wounds to the face from a 'Blue on Blue' incident.<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/5034672.stm]</ref><ref>[http://www.rctbusinessclub.co.uk/7820.html Rhondda Heritage Park’s Garden of Remembrance 2011] Rhondda Heritage Business Club</ref>
==Conservation== In 2010 concerns were made over the stability of the sculpture and that the resin material might disintegrate.<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/memorial-sculpture-at-risk-of-crumbling-away-2133550.html Memorial sculpture at risk of crumbling away] Independent</ref> Concerns were also raised about the sculpture's lack of a permanent display location. There have been attempts at petitioning for a more permanent location as well as fundraising efforts for a bronze version of the statue.
The sculpture now has a piece of music, commissioned by the TAS Project, written and sung by Bethan Myfanwy Hughes, a civilian trauma nurse and also a member of the Territorial Army.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fR-zgFcaE4U]</ref>

{{italic title}} {{Infobox artwork | title = The Birds | image_file = File:Sculpture of a House Sparrow at the Vancouver Olympic Village.jpg | caption = The sculpture seen through trees in 2011 | image_size = 300px | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = Myfanwy MacLeod | catalogue = | year = {{start date|2010}} <!--remove date template if before 1583 CE --> | type = Sculpture | material = | subject = [[House sparrow]]s | height_metric = | width_metric = | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. --> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. --> | condition = | city = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{Coord|49|16|17.06|N|123|6|23.38|W|}} | owner = | url = <!--{{URL|example.com}} Only for official web pages--> }}
'''''The Birds''''' comprises a pair of outdoor sculptures depicting [[house sparrow]]s by [[Myfanwy MacLeod]], installed after the [[2010 Winter Olympics]] in Southeast False Creek Olympic Plaza, which served as the site of the [[2010 Olympic Village]] in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada.<ref name=Globe>{{cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/when-giant-sparrows-attack/article1211261/|title=When giant sparrows attack|date=May 15, 2010|accessdate=September 6, 2014|first=Marsha|last=Lederman|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref><ref name=Jaunted>{{cite web|first=Tuija |last=Seipell |url=http://www.jaunted.com/story/2010/8/1/163512/4307/travel/Vancouver%92s+Coolest+Public+Art%3A+The+Birds+at+the+Olympic+Village |title=Vancouver’s Coolest Public Art: The Birds at the Olympic Village |publisher=Jaunted |date=August 3, 2010|accessdate=September 7, 2014}}</ref> The work depicts one male and one female house sparrow, each approximately five metres tall, and was the first piece approved by the city's Olympic and Paralympic Public Art Program. It was inspired by [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s [[The Birds (film)|1963 film of the same name]], sustainability, the site's history as a shipyard, and immigration.
They were removed on November 23, 2017 for repairs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.vancourier.com/news/olympic-village-s-giant-birds-headed-east-for-repairs-1.23103495|title=Olympic Village’s giant birds headed east for repairs|last=|first=|date=November 23, 2017 |work=Vancouver Courrier|accessdate=May 21, 2018}}</ref>
==Background== [[File:Sculpture of a sparrow in Olympic Village, Vancouver.jpg|thumb|left|upright|One of the house sparrows (2011)]]
''The Birds'' was the first work of public art to be approved under the city's Olympic and Paralympic Public Art Program.<ref name=Globe/><ref name=Jaunted/> It was installed in Southeast False Creek Olympic Plaza, which served as the site of the [[2010 Olympic Village]], in April 2010.<ref name=Globe/><ref name=Heavy>{{Cite web|url=http://heavyindustries.ca/the-birds/|accessdate=September 7, 2014|publisher=Heavy Industries|title=the birds: the skinny by heavy industries}}</ref> MacLeod was inspired by [[Alfred Hitchcock]]'s [[The Birds (film)|1963 film of the same name]]. She has said of the piece, "I think it boils down to wanting to make something sublime for the plaza – that is something beautiful, but frightening at the same time."<ref name=Globe/> She has also said of its inspiration:
{{Quote|We have a very kind of romantic relationship to nature and I'm interested in playing with that romantic notion and kind of inverting it, sort of like how the birds attack in the film… And the scale of [the installation] has that similar effect, where our relationship to the birds has changed. Because normally when you're on the plaza, you see little birds and you're this giant thing. Here it's the opposite: You're the small thing in relationship to the giant birds.<ref name=Globe/>}}
''The Birds'' was also inspired by sustainability and the site's history as a shipyard, where sailors often wore sparrow tattoos. The sculptures have been called an "ode to immigration" based on MacLeod's interest in "alien species" and when non-native species are introduced to an environment (the house sparrow is not native to North America).<ref name=Globe/><ref name=Jaunted/> MacLeod said: "My work for the Olympic Village tries to infuse the ordinary and commonplace sparrow with a touch of the ridiculous and the sublime. Locating this artwork in an urban plaza not only highlights what has become the 'natural' environment of the sparrow, it also reinforces the 'small' problem of introducing a foreign species and the subsequent havoc wreaked upon our ecosystems."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.canadiandesignresource.ca/nature/the-birds-installation/|title=The Birds Installation – Vancouver, British Columbia|accessdate=September 7, 2014|publisher=The Canadian Design Resource}}</ref>
The sculptures were produced by Heavy Industries, with some bodywork completed by Semi-Rigid Plastic Parts Repair.<ref name=Heavy/> ''The Birds'' was the last of the public art program's works to be installed, despite being the first approved.<ref name=Globe/>
==Description== [[File:Olympic Village, Vancouver (1).jpg|thumb|right|One of the sculptures in 2011]]
The work depicts one male and one female house sparrow, each between {{convert|4.5|and|5.5|m|ft|abbr=on}} tall,<ref name=Globe/><ref name=Jaunted/> or approximately {{nowrap|50 times}} life size.<ref name=Heavy/> The birds have been described as realistic and "massive yet friendly-looking".<ref name=Jaunted/><ref name=Heavy/> Their bodies are made from hard coated [[Polystyrene#Expanded_polystyrene|expanded polystyrene]] (EPS) foam, coated with a [[polyurea]] skin and airbrush painted, all clad around a steel armature. Their cast bronze legs were sealed with wax. According to Heavy, the EPS form pieces were "glued together with pressure-sensitive adhesive, specifically formulated for bonding EPS to itself and other materials".<ref name=Heavy/>
==Reception== Marsha Lederman of ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' called the sculptures "huge and intimidating and a bit creepy", but acknowledged the artist's intent.<ref name=Globe/> Explaining connection between immigration and sparrows specifically, she wrote that the birds were introduced "to satisfy cultural nostalgia for homesick Europeans. The birds were alien, exotic. They're now ubiquitous. Part of the everyday landscape. Barely noticed… Not these."<ref name=Globe/> Tuija Seipell of Jaunted said the sparrows were reminiscent of the bird that Flick and the Blueberries build to scare the Hoppers in the 1998 film ''[[A Bug's Life]]''.<ref name=Jaunted/>
==See also== * [[Public art in Vancouver]] * [[The Birds (story)|"The Birds" (story)]], a 1952 novelette by [[Daphne du Maurier]] and the inspiration for Hitchcock's film

{{Infobox book | name = The Excursion to Tilsit | image = | image_caption = | author = [[Hermann Sudermann]] | title_orig = Litauische Geschichten | translator = Lewis Galantière | country = Germany | language = German | publisher = J.G. Cotta | pub_date = 1917 | english_pub_date = 1930 | pages = 488 }} '''''The Excursion to Tilsit''''' is a 1917 collection of short stories or novellas by the German writer [[Hermann Sudermann]]. Its German title is '''''Litauische Geschichten''''', which means "Lithuanian stories". The book consists of four stories set in rural Lithuania in the mid 19th century. It was published in English in 1930, translated by Lewis Galantière.{{Cite web|url=http://www.worldcat.org/title/excursion-to-tilsit/oclc/1474999|title=The excursion to Tilsit|work=[[WorldCat]]|accessdate=2015-09-25}} Several stories from the book have been adapted for film. Most famously, [[F. W. Murnau]]'s 1927 film ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'' is loosely based on the titular story.{{Cite book|last=Fischer|first=Lucy|year=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V96tee1l2q8C&pg=PA75|chapter=Sunrise: A Tale of Two Humans|editor1-last=White|editor1-first=Rob|editor2-last=Buscombe|editor2-first=Edward|title=British Film Institute Film Classics, Volume 1|location=London; New York|publisher=[[British Film Institute]]; [[Fitzroy Dearborn Publishers|Fitzroy Dearborn]]|page=75|isbn=1-57958-328-8}} ==Stories and plots== '''The Excursion to Tilsit''' (Die Reise nach Tilsit)
A married man is in love with his mistress and plans to drown his wife on the way back from a trip to [[Sovetsk, Kaliningrad Oblast|Tilsit]]. During the trip he reconciles with his wife, changes his mind and tells her about his now abandoned plan. In a fatal accident the man drowns and the wife is saved through the means the man had prepared for his own escape.
'''Miks Bumbullis'''
A murderer needs to visit the grave of his daughter to please the goddess of death, despite knowing that the police will be there waiting for him.
'''Jons and Erdma''' (Jons und Erdme)
A couple become wealthy by the means of tricks and foul play. Eventually they are in turn tricked by their daughters and have to start again from zero.
'''The Hired Girl''' (Die Magd) ==Reception== Margaret Wallace of ''[[The Bookman (New York)|The Bookman]]'' wrote:
Like [[Selma Lagerlöf]], and many other novelists whose material is national and even provincial, Sudermann by his very unconcern with cosmopolitan values gives a deeper truth and meaning to the lives of his characters. Of these four stories of Lithuanian peasants, only one, "Miks Bumbullis", depends for its effect upon purely national traits and circumstances. They are, for the most part, founded solidly upon the fundamental and inescapable human facts of birth and love and death. They are moving and tragic and, above all, intensely and vividly alive.{{Cite web|last=Wallace|first=Margaret|year=April 1930|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/Bookman-1930apr-00214a03|title=''The Excursion to Tilsit'' by Hermann Sudermann|work=[[The Bookman (New York)|The Bookman]]|page=214-215}}
''[[The Outlook (New York)|The Outlook]]'' reviewed the book:
''Excursion to Tilsit'' by Hermann Sudermann is a collection of powerful short stories dealing with the life of Lithuanian peasants. The author has observed them sympathetically and at first hand. Nominal Catholics, they still live in fear of pagan gods, giving even their lives to propitiate them. ... Among the stories, that of Jons and Erdma who, having built a home by tricks and cunning are tricked out of it at last by their daughters, compares favorably with [[Ivan Turgenev|Turgeniev's]] ''Lear of the Steppes'' as a story of faith and treachery.{{Cite web|date=1930-04-02|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/Outlook-1930apr02-00544a02|title=The Leisure Arts: The Week's Reading|work=[[The Outlook (New York)|The Outlook]]|page=546}}
==Film adaptations== * ''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'', 1927, directed by [[F. W. Murnau]] * ''[[The Journey to Tilsit]]'', 1939, directed by [[Veit Harlan]] * ''[[Jons und Erdme]]'', 1959, directed by [[Victor Vicas]] * ''Reise nach Tilsit'', 1969, TV film, directed by Günter Gräwert * ''Miks Bumbullis'', 1971, TV film, directed by Günter Gräwert * ''The Excursion to Paradise'', 1980, directed by Arūnas Žebriūnas ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://archive.org/details/litauischegeschi00sudeuoft ''Litauische Geschichten''] at [[Internet Archive]] {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/die-reise-nach-tilsit-1984/1 Die Reise nach Tilsit] at [[Projekt Gutenberg-DE]] {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/miks-bumbullis-1986/1 Miks Bumbullis] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/jons-und-erdme-1992/1 Jons und Erdme] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} * [http://gutenberg.spiegel.de/buch/die-magd-1990/1 Die Magd] at Projekt Gutenberg-DE {{De icon}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Excursion to Tilsit}} [[Category:1917 short story collections]] [[Category:Books adapted into films]] [[Category:German short story collections]] [[Category:German-language literature]] [[Category:Lithuania in fiction]] [[Category:Works by Hermann Sudermann]]

{{sources|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Tosun Bayrak | birth_name = Tosun Bekir Bayraktaroğlu<ref>[http://www.sufi.com.tr/kitaplar/ani-biyografi/amerikada-bir-turk.aspx Amerika'da Bir Türk]</ref> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1926|01|21}}<ref>Amerika'da Bir Türk [http://www.sufi.com.tr/kitaplar/ani-biyografi/amerikada-bir-turk.aspx], p.19</ref> | birth_place = [[Istanbul]], [[Turkey]] | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|02|15|1926|01|21}} | residence = [[New York (state)|New York]], United States | occupation = Sufi sheikh, writer, translator, artist | spouse = Jean Linder Bayrak | website = {{URL|tosunbayrak.com}} | footnotes = }} {{Sufism}} '''Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi al-Halveti''' (January 21, 1926 – 15 February 2018) was an author, translator and [[Sufi]]. He served as a government official in [[Ankara]], Honorary Consul of [[Turkey]] in [[Morocco]] and was the Sheikh of the [[Jerrahi]] Order in America.<ref>[http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html The Tree of Being] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516072115/http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html |date=2008-05-16 }}</ref> He died on February 15, 2018.<ref>[https://www.alaturka.us/obituary-sufi-leader-tosun-bayraktaroglu/ Obituary: Sufi leader Tosun Bayraktaroglu]</ref>
==Biography== ===Early life=== Bayrak was born in [[Istanbul]] in 1926.<ref name=obit>Ahmet Sait Akcay, [https://www.aa.com.tr/en/culture-and-art/obituary-sufi-leader-tosun-bayraktaroglu/1069998 Obituary: Sufi leader Tosun Bayraktaroglu]. Andalou Agency, 21 February 2018. Accessed 28 October 2018.</ref> During his childhood, he'd been raised without religion in the household, having rarely visited a mosque with his parents; his interest in Hindu and Buddhist philosopher during high school was one of his few experiences with religion.<ref name=moth>Matt Hanson, [https://www.dailysabah.com/arts-culture/2018/09/01/the-moth-and-the-flame-in-memory-of-tosun-bayrak The moth and the flame: In memory of Tosun Bayrak]. [[Daily Sabah]], 31 August 2018. Accessed 28 October 2018.</ref> Early in life, his grandfather helped to spark his interest in art and poetry with trips to museums as well as [[Topkapı Palace]].<ref name=moth/> Initially, he studied [[Biological Sciences]] at [[Robert College]], graduating in 1945.<ref name=obit/> It was during his time in college that he first became exposed to Islam as a living practice, lodging on weekends with his aunt who prayed five times a day and fasted during [[Ramadan]].<ref name=moth/>
Bayrak later went on to study [[Art]], [[Architecture]], and [[Art History]] in the Studios of [[Fernand Léger]] and [[Andre Lhote]] in [[Paris]];<ref name=moth/> [[Architecture]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]];<ref name=obit/> and [[History of Art]] at the [[Courtauld Institute of Art]], [[London]]. While in London, he was an associate of poet [[Can Yücel]] and former [[Prime Minister of Turkey]] [[Bülent Ecevit]].<ref name=moth/> He received a Masters in Fine Arts from [[Rutgers University]].<ref name=obit/>
===Sufism=== In 1970 Bayrak met [[Muzaffer Ozak]], who became his spiritual teacher, at the Jerrahi Lodge in Instanbul.<ref name=obit/><ref>William Rory Dickson, [https://books.google.com.sa/books?id=HCiLCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA3&dq=jerrahi+america&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjj0IvShLDeAhUMC8AKHfz9BuQQ6AEILzAB#v=onepage&q=jerrahi%20america&f=false Living Sufism in North America: Between Tradition and Transformation], p. 108. [[Albany, New York|Albany]]: [[SUNY Press]], 2015. {{ISBN|9781438457581}}</ref> Bayrak became a Sheikh of the Halveti-Jerrahi order and resided near the Jerrahi Order of America mosque in [[Spring Valley, New York]] a few years later.<ref>[http://www.sufism.org/books/names.html#tosun The Most Beautiful Names]</ref> He acted as the spiritual guide of the Jerrahi Order of the Americas starting from 1977,<ref>[http://www.forusa.org/fellowship/sep_oct_01/1001_13.html The Meaning of Age] {{Webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20040626145532/http://www.forusa.org/fellowship/sep_oct_01/1001_13.html |date=2004-06-26 }}</ref>, and he founded the official mosque of the Order's American branch in [[Chestnut Ridge, New York]] in 1990.<ref name=moth/> Though at one time an admirer of [[Fethullah Gülen]], Bayrak condemned the [[Gülen movement]] at a winter 2016 art exhibit in Istanbul due to the movement's alleged involvement in the [[2016 Turkish coup d'état attempt]].<ref name=moth/>
{{cquote|“Service should be from the moment you are born until the moment you give your last breath, but you have to find out in what way. That's what's most important. We have to find out in what manner we are supposed to serve.” <ref>"The World is Beautiful" An interview with Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi [http://www.wie.org/j18/bayrak.asp?page=2]</ref>}}
In response to the [[January 2015 Île-de-France attacks]], which ended as Bayrak was planning a Friday sermon, he declared that the perpetrators were insane, not Muslims, and opposed the key teachings of Islam.<ref>Jane Lerner and Richard Liebson, [https://www.lohud.com/story/news/local/2015/01/09/local-muslims-jews-horrified-terror-france/21530145/ Local Muslims, Jews horrified by terror in Paris]. [[The Journal News]], 9 January 2015. Accessed 1 November 2018.</ref> Bayrak passed away in New York on 15 February 2018 at the age of 92.<ref name=obit/>
==Works== ===Artisty=== Bayrak taught art and art history at [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]], where he helped to establish the Fine Arts Division.<ref name=moth/> His work was exhibited widely in the United States,<ref>[http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html The Tree of Being] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080516072115/http://www.fonsvitae.com/tosunbayrakibnarabi.html |date=2008-05-16 }}</ref> and he became a [[John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation|Guggenheim]] fellow in 1965.<ref name=moth/><ref>[http://www.worldwisdom.com/Public/Authors/Detail.asp?AuthorID=97&WhatType=1 Tosun Bayrak]</ref> He retired from the art world in the 1970s and devoted his life to the study and teaching of [[Islam]] and Sufism.
{{cquote|“Both my wife and I were artists, and we felt very strongly that it was feeding our egos. Art, art exhibitions, and the consequences of being accepted and successful are incredible food for your ego, which is the Sufi's enemy. The final straw was when we went to Rome to visit a friend, a sculptor, and there was a very pretty young girl there whom my friend introduced me to. And she was so adoring to me. She said, "Ohhh, I know you. I love your art." She was completely praising me, and I saw the ego suddenly rise up and say, "Aha! This beautiful, spiritual girl is telling you that you are a great artist." So I said, "Oh, my God! That's it. It's over." I hit the ego on the head and decided I was finished with it all.<ref>"The World is Beautiful" An interview with Sheikh Tosun Bayrak al-Jerrahi [http://www.wie.org/j18/bayrak.asp?page=2]</ref>}}
===Translation=== Bayrak translated dozens of books on Islamic spirituality, but he was particularly known for his efforts on the works of the Sufi mystic [[Ibn Arabi]]. One of his best known works is ''Ibn Arabi: The Tree of Being''. His translations of classic works of Sufism include [[Abdul Qadir Gilani]]'s ''Secret of Secrets'', ''Inspirations'', and ''The Book of Sufi Chivalry'', ''[[Suhrawardiyya|Suhrawardi]]: The Shape of Light'', ''The Name and the Named: Divine Attributes of God'', and [[Imam Birgivi]]'s ''The Path of Muhammad''.<ref name=obit/>

{{Italic title|reason=[[:Category:Japanese words and phrases]]}} [[Image:Japanese Secret Puzzle Box.jpg|thumb|Japanese yosegi puzzle box]] [[Image:Japanese Yosegi Jewelry Box.jpg|thumb|Japanese yosegi jewelry box]] {{Nihongo|'''''Yosegi-zaiku'''''|寄木細工}} is a type of traditional Japanese [[marquetry]] which originated during Japan's culturally rich [[Edo period]]. It has become widely known and respected throughout the world. The mosaic work is made by making use of natural fine grains and textures of wood. Timbers of different colors are cut into oblong rods of desired sections. Spindle tree (''[[Euonymus]]'' spp.) and ''[[Ilex macropoda]]'' are used for white, aged Katsura tree (''[[Cercidiphyllum japonicum]]'') for black, ''[[Picrasma quassioides]]'', mulberry (''[[Morus alba]]'') and Chinese lacquer tree (''[[Toxicodendron vernicifluum]]'') for yellow, camphor tree (''[[Cinnamomum camphora]]'') and ''[[Maackia]]'' for brown, black walnut (''[[Juglans nigra]]'') for purple, Japanese cucumber tree (''[[Magnolia obovata]]'') for blue and Chinese cedar (''[[Toona sinensis]]'') for red. The rods are then glued together to form the section of geometrical design pattern. The sectional surface is sliced into thin plates of wood, which are glued onto boxes and other handicraft works. To add to the glaze and sturdiness of the surface, finishing coatings of [[lacquer]] are applied.
Yosegi are commonly found on the outside of Japanese secret boxes or [[Puzzle box|puzzle boxes]], but may also be used to create or decorate many other items such as trays, chests, jewellery boxes, vases, photo frames, drink coasters, etc.
